citeinfo.origin: Colorado Natural Heritage Program/Colorado State University
citeinfo.title: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site Vegetation Mapping Project - Spatial Vegetation Data

descript.abstract: High resolution vegetation polygons mapped by the National Park Service. Multivariate ordination and clustering analyses were used to classify the vegetation. As a result, six plant associations of the National Vegetation Classification (NVC) were identified and locally described. To produce the vegetation map, both National Agriculture Imagery Program 1:12,000-scale, true color, digital ortho-imagery acquired in 2006 and the USDA-FSA-APFO Digital Ortho Mosaic for Kiowa County were used in conjunction with field data to identify vegetation signatures. Four additional non-natural mapping units were devised from the plot and observation point data to complete the map.
descript.purpose: Vegetation maps of National Parks and National Monuments were developed to support natural resources management, planning, research and interpretation.
descript.supplinf: Data were imported to a file geodatabase by the Colorado Natural Heritage Program/Colorado State University. Parks had the flexibility to map vegetation down to the map class or to the association. Refer to sandrpt.pdf for more detailed information. The shapefile was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis.

spdom.descgeog: Sand Creek Massacre National Historic Site and environs

idinfo.accconst: It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from U.S. Geological Survey and National Park Service servers and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.0 (Build 6002) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

procstep.procdesc: Back in the office, ecologists used field data and 2005 aerial photos (National Agriculture Imagery Program, 2005) to map draft vegetation polygons in ArcGIS personal geodatabase. Table relationships were used to create a drop-down list of Associations in the attribute table to ensure consistent data entry. GIS Specialist then cleaned the layer topology, removing gaps, slivers, and any data inconsistencies.
The Shapefile was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis.
